senses.de: A situation in which people or organizations try to do better than others
senses.ex: There's a lot of competition between computer companies.

Tips.title: Beyond Business
Tips.description: Not limited to companies; it also occurs in sports, academics, and art.
Tips.example: The competition for the best science project was intense among students.

Tips.title: Emotional Impact
Tips.description: Often implies stress or challenge, as participants strive to outdo each other.
Tips.example: As the competition heated up, the athletes felt more pressure.

Tips.title: Common Confusion
Tips.description: Don't confuse 'competition' (the situation) with 'competitor' (a person or entity involved).
Tips.example: She respected the competition but was not friends with her competitors.

senses.de: An event or contest in which people compete
senses.ex: She has entered several competitions this year.

Tips.title: Wide Usage
Tips.description: Refers to diverse events, from official tournaments to casual workplace contests.
Tips.example: The annual baking competition attracts amateur chefs from around the country.

Tips.title: Evolving Definition
Tips.description: In tech and gaming, it can refer to online contests not confined to a single location.
Tips.example: He won the coding competition that was held entirely online.

Tips.title: Informal Expressions
Tips.description: In casual contexts, people use 'competition' to describe rivalry in playful scenarios.
Tips.example: Among friends, the competition to finish eating a pizza the fastest was in good fun.

senses.de: The activity of striving to gain or win something by defeating others
senses.ex: They thrive under conditions of competition.

Tips.title: Degree of Intensity
Tips.description: Adjectives describe the intensity, such as 'fierce' or 'friendly', changing the tone.
Tips.example: The small shops faced fierce competition from the new mall.

Tips.title: Larger Context
Tips.description: Always consider the context to understand if 'competition' is beneficial or harmful.
Tips.example: Healthy competition can drive innovation, but can also lead to unethical practices.

Tips.title: Market Forces
Tips.description: In business, it influences prices, quality, and availability of products and services.
Tips.example: Competition among streaming services has drastically increased original content.

Battle.wordDefinition:
A battle involves fighting or struggling against an enemy or opponent, usually in a physical or violent manner.

Therefore, battles are applicable in situations where there is a need to fight, either in war or in self-defense. Competitions are applicable in situations where there is a need to showcase one's abilities or skills, such as in sports, academic, or talent competitions.

Conflict.wordDefinition:
Conflict refers to a situation where two or more individuals or groups have opposing views, interests or beliefs and are actively working against each other.

It can be negative and destructive, leading to hostility and sometimes violence. For example, a political conflict where two parties are fighting over a policy decision.

Competition is seen as healthy and positive while conflict is negative and destructive. Competition involves striving for excellence while conflict involves power struggles and opposition.

Contest.wordDefinition:
Contest is a situation where people are competing to win a prize or award, usually based on a specific skill or talent.

Examples include singing contests, art contests, or essay contests.

Competition is a broader term that can refer to any situation where people are vying against each other, while a contest typically involves a specific activity or skill set.

Duel.wordDefinition:
Competition and duel are both related to a contest or contesting, but there is a difference in their nature and application.

A duel is a one-on-one contest between two individuals that often involves weapons and is fought to prove one's honor or settle a dispute.

Duels were more common in the past and are now illegal in most countries.

A competition can be any contest where individuals or teams compete against each other, while a duel is a specific type of contest involving two individuals fighting to prove their worth or settle a disagreement.

Match.wordDefinition:
Competition and match are two words that are used in relation to sports or games, but they have slightly different meanings.

It can include multiple matches or games within it.

A match is a specific instance of competition, often between two individuals or teams playing a particular game. It usually involves a set of rules, a specific location, and a defined time.

In sports, a match often involves two teams or players competing against each other directly, and the winner is determined by who scores more points or achieves victory according to the rules of the game.

For example, in football, a match refers to a game between two teams where each team tries to score more goals than the other.

A competition is a series of events where individuals or teams compete against each other, while a match is a specific game or event within that competition.

Race.wordDefinition:
Race is specifically an event in which individuals compete against each other in a disorderly manner. It's often focused on speed and time, such as running races or car races.

Competition refers to a broader range of activities, while a race is typically a more specific type of competition focused on speed or timing.

Rivalry.wordDefinition:
Rivalry refers to a situation where two or more individuals or groups engage in intense competition marked by a deep-seated animosity, bitterness, and resentment towards each other.

In simpler terms, competition is a healthy form of challenging oneself to do better, while rivalry involves an intense and negative desire to beat the other person.

Rivalry is applicable when two opposing groups or individuals have a long-standing history of conflict or when there is a strong personal dislike between them.

Tussle.wordDefinition:
Tussle implies a physical or metaphorical struggle, often with no clear goal or rules.

Tussle is often used in more informal, personal contexts, where conflict or confrontation may occur.

quotes.Text: I have been up against tough competition all my life. I wouldn't know how to get along without it.
quotes.Title: American Businessman
quotes.Name: Walt Disney

quotes.Text: I'm not afraid to lose. I'm here for the competition. I'm here to make greatness.
quotes.Title: American Boxer
quotes.Name: Keith Thurman

quotes.Text: Life is nothing but a competition to be the criminal rather than the victim.
quotes.Title: British Philosopher
quotes.Name: Bertrand Russell

quotes.Text: It's important to take every game seriously, whatever the competition is.
quotes.Title: French Athlete
quotes.Name: Hugo Lloris

quotes.Text: It's really important that people don't view success as a competition.
quotes.Title: English Actress
quotes.Name: Karla Crome

quotes.Text: There is no life without sport and no sport without competition.
quotes.Title: Indian Actor
quotes.Name: Randeep Hooda

quotes.Text: I have always had a passion for competition and performance.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Eve Torres

quotes.Text: The most important competition is always the next match.
quotes.Title: Armenian Athlete
quotes.Name: Henrikh Mkhitaryan

quotes.Text: The competition in today's world of racing is so tough.
quotes.Title: American Driver
quotes.Name: Jimmie Johnson

quotes.Text: I live for competition. It makes my life complete.
quotes.Title: American Athlete
quotes.Name: Hope Solo
